body: @csantanapr that's the hope. PG 366.
@rabbah, @csantanapr, I'll work on squashing, and the additive issues tonight. As far as the review goes, I hope it is not too strict as the Go CLI is not finished.

@csantanapr, @rabbah, @markusthoemmes, @psuter, I'm going to leave this pull request open as it runs the Go CLI against the Whisk automation. Please refer to pull request #604 for what we want merged ASAP. That request only adds the go-cli folder with the Go CLI source code to the tools directory, nothing more.

@csantanapr could you please take a look at the Vagrant readme? There are some particular changes that affect the way we do set up the local db.
- template-couchdb-local.env and template-cloudant-local.env are obsolete. both cases are handled by db_local.ini
- the user does not need to edit and copy the template files anymore. only run setup.yml.
- vagrant custom should work as before, user can provide OW_DB_xxx variables that are forwarded to ansible
- vagrant simple should also work as before, uses couchdb as backend. difference is only that start-couchdb-box.sh and createImmortalDBs.sh are no longer used. instead ansible does the work.

All ansible-related changes are documented in the ansible/README.md, so you may want to just link to it where applicable or use it as input for the general README.md.
Yes.

Any lessons learned for the future on this incident? Any actions to handle it better, notifications, prevent, etc..?

We should consider depending on fixed commits in their history, I think. Pulling from the latest is a recipe for disaster as we've seen when they break it, and also for surprises when a sterilized build jumps over many versions at once due to Docker caching.

On the downside, it's more work for us to port their improvements, which are still frequent at this early stage of development for Swift on Linux.
I agree then let's open an issue to discuss and move forward with what are the changes we need short term and long term.

Darwin carlosmac.ibm.com 15.5.0 Darwin Kernel Version 15.5.0: Tue Apr 19 18:36:36 PDT 2016; root:xnu-3248.50.21~8/RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64

No other VMs are running

```
$ rm -rf ~/.vagrant.d/
$ git clone --depth=1 https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk.git
$ cd openwhisk/tools/vagrant/simple/
$ ./hello

wait for a while, downloading new vagrant ubuntu to cache (10 minutes) then whisk setup (20 minutes)

}
```

@csantanapr I have run a travis build that does install a vagrant box. It would work in theory, however you need to install virtualbox first which in conjunction with our own build + test flow takes longer than travis allows on the free tier and the build gets killed. I suggest making a build on our Jenkins that does a vagrant up and checks the output.

@lfzCarlosC Ah I think you are hitting some of the UX, we are seeing and working on fixing.
Restarting I think will cause problems, since you have to deploy `ant deploy` but the inmortal DB is not up. @houshengbo is working on fixing this workflow.

For now don't restart the VM, just suspend it and then up (not resume). you can use vagrant cli, we have that in the [simple/README.md(https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/vagrant/simple/README.md)

```
# Suspend vagrant vm when done having fun
  vagrant suspend

# Resume vagrant vm to have fun again
  vagrant up
```
Closing then as discussion on how to handle this is going on in a different issue.

("*.go",       [ has_block_copyright, line_checks([ no_tabs, no_trailing_spaces, eol_at_eof ]) ])

@sjfink, this pull request is just for the Go CLI source code, it does not modify the build process in anyway as we want to get some source code in ASAP. However, I have another pull request open just for the purpose of running the Go CLI against all the automation in the TravisCI build. All tests there are passing. I am currently working on getting the Jenkins builds to pass using the Go CLI.

I sat with James I did a review, here are my findings.

## 1. Things to fix in the PR to merge it in:

Add Readme.md to go-cli/README.md
Remove "BlueMix" from go-cli/go-whisk-cli/Godeps
Delete go-cli/go-whisk-cli/notes.md
Remove everything except `Godeps/_worspace` from go-cli/.gitignore

Add to the README.md the use of the env variable WSK_CLI_DEBUG

Move properties to config.xml
    <property name="go-cli.build.dir"        value="${basedir}/build/tools/go-cli" />
    <property name="go-cli.src.dir"          value="${basedir}/tools/go-cli" />

## 2. Action items outside this PR:
- look into depenencies versions we are currently using (go-whiks-cli/Godeps/Godeps.json)
- look into GoVersion declare (1.5)go-whiks-cli/Godeps/Godeps.json)
- `wsk property get` doesn't return info like python cli, need to pass --all
- wsk cli apihost is hardcoded to (openwhisk.ng.bluemix.net), and it should be set to the value of edge.host from whisk.properties (i.e. edge.host=172.17.0.1)
- the order of the properties don't mathc the python cli output with `wsk property get`
- Positional parameters are not documented like python cli

```
wsk action create <name string> <artifact string> [flags]
the should be like this or similar: human description for the paramters
positional arguments:
  name                  the name of the action
  artifact              artifact (e.g., file name) containing action
                        definition
```
- Need to print a new line after ok result when creating a new action

```
$ ./wsk action create myaction myaction.js
ok: created action myactionvagrant@vagrant-ubuntu-trusty-64:~/openwhisk/bin/go-cli/linux/amd64$
```
- can't pass numbers as parameters 

```
./wsk -v action invoke myaction --blocking --result -p foo [1,2,3]
They get pass as string array instead of number array
Req Body
{{"foo":["1","2","3"]}
}

- Pinned the versions of the dependencies, we should not have a dependency against the head/master of the git repo, relying on their repos to be available, and assume they don't do something that will break our CLI is a recipe for disaster. We can always update and refresh the dependency on a regular cadence.

In the python CLI it get's pass as numbers
Body sent:
{"foo": [1, 2, 3]}
In python to pass strings you need to escape with quotes
 ./wsk -v action invoke myaction --blocking --result -p foo [\"1\",\"2\",\"3\"]
 Body sent:
{"foo": ["1", "2", "3"]}
```

## 3. Tips to improve later:
- make env variables to only build one binary making dev cycle faster
- look into implementing a watch/make task to automatically compile on source code change 
- upgrade version of from 1.6 to 1.7, 1.7 is GA
- implement autocomplete for CLI ( we have recommendations when typos, but autocomplete will be also good to have)s

There's an issue with these tests - I missed it initially.

`val api = new RestAPIVersion_v1(config, Verbosity.Loud, actorSystem, actorSystem.dispatcher)`

this actually creates a controller which means it will access a consul server and an entitlement server if they exist - which if tested in the context of a deployed system will in fact exist. this will cause the last test to fail since that tests creates a temporary subject which will fail authorization.

one could simply tests against a live controller - and simplify the unit test. I will attempt to correct (see #613).

> Regardless if you restart the VM the whisk system doesn't start automatically, you need to deploy/start the whisk system.

@csantanapr not entirely true. The system should come back up in general. Ephemeral couch is a different story, however. If you use cloudant or other peristent db it should recover from a reboot. Part of our RAS strategy.

@tuler this might be a topic that might interest you.

I think that comparing to other _serverless_ architectures is important because it improves the understanding and adoption of openwhisk.

Regarding the callback, I agree that #56 is very welcome, especially for modern node runtimes.

### Comparing to AWS Lambda

AWS tweaked the programming model in the node 4.3 runtime, as opposed to the 0.10 runtime.
Currently the function prototype is:

`function (event, context, callback)`
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/nodejs-prog-model-handler.html

The [Context](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/nodejs-prog-model-context.html) object holds metadata of the function and about the execution environment, including auth.

The user has to call `callback(error, result)`, so it's async-only.

### Comparing to Google Cloud Function

Google requires the user to package it's function as a npm module. The function prototype is:
`function (context, data)`
https://cloud.google.com/functions/writing

The `context` provides methods for function termination, `context.done`, much like openwhisk.
`Data` is the event.

### Comparing to Microsoft Azure Function

Azure's function prototype is event shorter:
`function(context)`
https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/documentation/articles/functions-reference-node/

You end execution with `context.done`. You get event data also from the `context` object.

Global main is definitely not ideal. Export is the way to go. It also enables the use of several functions in the same file.

I think webpack'ing is a nice option, but I think it should not be required. Some options to consider:
- single file only (webpack)
- zip of whole folder with dependencies installed
- or even zip including package.json and 'npm install'ed by the openwhisk container.
These are probably due to #199, as the container gets removed anyway, the error is ignored by ansible.
+1 on including it in `/api/v1`. Or go super fancy: Include it in `OPTIONS /api/v1/namespaces/_/actions`

I think is safe to take the yaml (Go) as dependency, they have an exception in their [ yaml (Go) License](https://github.com/go-yaml/yaml/blob/v2/LICENSE)

> As a special exception to the GNU Lesser General Public License version 3
> ("LGPL3"), the copyright holders of this Library give you permission to
> convey to a third party a Combined Work that links statically or dynamically
> to this Library without providing any Minimal Corresponding Source or
> Minimal Application Code as set out in 4d or providing the installation
> information set out in section 4e,...

I give   to merge it in I will wait for a second  as @rr requested in https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/604#issuecomment-224962429

> Wait for two thumbs up please.

I added new TODO in my comment above https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/604#issuecomment-224987914:

> - Pinned the versions of the dependencies, we should not have a dependency against the head/master of the git repo, relying on their repos to be available, and assume they don't do something that will break our CLI is a recipe for disaster. We can always update and refresh the dependency on a regular cadence.

@tuler webpack, was just an example, I agree it should NOT be required.

And the other alternatives like using a zip is good to have.

I didn't get your 3rd example

> or even zip including package.json and 'npm install'ed by the openwhisk container.

You mean a small zip with only the action.js and package.json? and let whisk do the npm install using the package.json?

Yes. Like you do when you commit your node app to git, excluding node_modules using .gitignore.

But I'm not sold on this idea.
Obviously you would have to `npm install` beforehand, because it takes some time.

Yeah the penalty in time to invoke an action to get the container warm you would need to wait for npm install, and also hope npm registry or any url your fetching is up :-)

But for simple debugging and dev time, it might be useful. 
I have being thinking that there might be a `prod` vs. `dev` invocations or creations, that allows dev to hack away even open a port to the debugger so they can breakpoint and everything from their IDE/editor.

> +1 on including it in /api/v1. Or go super fancy: Include it in OPTIONS /api/v1/namespaces/_/actions

I'm fine with either as long whiskswagger.json get's updated

i think there is benefit in not doing npm install on the server side, since it forces the developer to send over exactly what he wants to be run. i've seen too often issues due to code working on the client side, but didn't work on the server-side since different versions of dependencies were pulled

I think I agree @mbehrendt 

Regarding the invoke penalty, I suggested this because I was playing with an architecture that I build a docker image for each function (from a base runtime image) and register it in a private registry. So each function has its docker image. The name of the image is the name of the function.
yeah, that is a good point. i think in some other issue, @csantanapr had suggested that as well? adding @perryibm , since there might be perf considerations around this
Maybe #575 can be part of the solution/implementation? (although somewhat orthogonal, but this certainly makes feeds more prominent in the API in general)

I can't find the issue now, but in general if I was going into production with an app that every ms counts and I need the highest level of control using a container will be the way to go.

and app with multiple dependencies then you can burn this into the container image, no need to fetch the zip of dependencies on cold start.
more control on what version of the runtime language if you are required to use specific version nodejs:4.2.1, or a special binary of nodejs with static link compiled dependencies.

More effort for a novice developer to get this level of control and setup, but this is where some tooling, samples, templates, sdk can come handy to abstract those specific to metadata and developer just worry about the code that will eventually goes into the container.

Unfortunately, using many docker images wouldn't be free either because the image has to get pulled from some registry.  Since we have many invokers and things are quite dynamic, any particular activation might end up having to pull an image as part of its cold start.  It might be useful to intercept in the middle and freeze an image after the dependencies but before the user code and re-use these images which are more likely to be share-able.
Another instance in [google group](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/openwhisk/zsop0EXmRzo) of someone struggling with REST API creating triggers.

One way to overcome, some of this is to use a single image, and build monolitic app with a facade, where it's actually the same docker image, creating multiple actions with same artifact where bound parameters decide which code to run. or creating a single action that handles all events.

Yeah I agree cold start of unknown image will need to get downloaded, but once download I believe we cache the image.

I don't see pulling the image as a big problem if a private registry is part of the architecture. But you have a better understanding of openwhisk architecture to judge it, I'm just starting to play with the code.
